factoid: Nicholas did not see Daniel before the chestnut dog panted past him.
Nicholas did not hear Daniel before the chestnut dog panted past him.
Chestnut is a dog that breathed heavily and panted past Nicholas.
Chestnut heard the fall of a body.
Chestnut saw Daniel lying on the wolf's back among the dogs.
Daniel was lying on the wolf's back among the dogs.
Daniel was trying to seize the wolf by the ears.
The dogs, the hunters, and the wolf all realized that the situation was over.
The wolf pressed back her ears.
The wolf tried to rise.
The borzois stuck to the wolf.
Daniel rose a little.
Daniel took a step.
Daniel fell on the wolf with his whole weight.
Daniel seized the wolf by the ears.
Nicholas was about to stab the wolf.
Daniel whispered "Don't! We'll gag her!" to Nicholas.
Daniel changed his position.
Daniel set his foot on the wolf's neck.
A stick was thrust between the wolf's jaws.
The wolf was fastened with a leash.
The wolf's legs were bound together.
Daniel rolled the wolf over once or twice from side to side.
The group laid the old wolf on a shying and snorting horse.
The dogs yelped at the wolf.
The group took the wolf to the place where they were to meet.
The hounds killed two cubs.
The borzois killed three cubs.
The huntsmen assembled with their booty and stories.
The huntsmen looked at the wolf.
The wolf had a broad-browed head hanging down.
The wolf had a bitten stick between her jaws.
The wolf gazed with great glassy eyes at the crowd of dogs and men surrounding her.
When the wolf was touched, she jerked her bound legs.
The wolf looked wildly yet simply at everybody.
Old Count Rostóv rode up.
Old Count Rostóv touched the wolf.
Old Count Rostóv said "Oh, what a formidable one!"
Old Count Rostóv asked Daniel "A formidable one, eh?"
Daniel was standing near.
Daniel answered "Yes, your excellency."
Daniel quickly doffed his cap.
The count remembered the wolf he had let slip.
The count remembered his encounter with Daniel.
The count said "Ah, but you are a crusty fellow, friend!"
Daniel gave the count a shy, childlike, meek, and amiable smile.
The old count went home.
Natásha promised to return very soon.
Pétya promised to return very soon.
The hunt went farther.
At midday, they put the hounds into a ravine thickly overgrown with young trees.
Nicholas stood in a fallow field.
Nicholas could see all his whips.
Facing Nicholas lay a field of winter rye.
Nicholas's huntsman stood alone in a hollow behind a hazel bush.
The hounds had scarcely been loosed.
Nicholas heard Voltórn, a hound he knew, giving tongue at intervals.
Other hounds joined in, pausing and giving tongue.
Nicholas heard a cry from the wooded ravine that a fox had been found.
The whole pack rushed along the ravine toward the ryefield and away from Nicholas.
Nicholas saw the whips in their red caps galloping along the edge of the ravine.
Nicholas saw the hounds.
Nicholas expected a fox to show itself at any moment on the ryefield opposite.
The huntsman moved and loosed his borzois.
Nicholas saw a queer, short-legged red fox with a fine brush going hard across the field.
The borzois bore down on the fox.
The fox began to dodge between the field in sharper and sharper curves, trailing its brush.
A strange white borzoi dashed in.
A black borzoi followed the white one.
The borzois formed a star-shaped figure, scarcely swaying their bodies.
The borzois had tails turned away from the center of the group.
Two huntsmen galloped up to the dogs.
One huntsman wore a red cap.
The other huntsman wore a green coat.
Nicholas thought "What's this?"
Nicholas thought "Where's that huntsman from?"
Nicholas thought "He is not 'Uncle's' man."
The huntsmen got the fox.
The huntsmen stayed there a long time without strapping the fox to the saddle.
Their horses were bridled and had high saddles.
The horses stood near the huntsmen.
The dogs were lying near the horses.
The huntsmen waved their arms.
The huntsmen did something to the fox.
A horn sounded from that spot.
The horn was the signal agreed on in case of a fight.
Nicholas' groom said "That's Ilágin's huntsman having a row with our Iván."
Nicholas sent the man to call Natásha and Pétya to him.
Nicholas rode at a foot pace to the place where the whips were getting the hounds together.
Several of the field galloped to the spot where the fight was going on.
